meta.title: Wheel of Life Assessment: Discipline Layer
meta.definition: Consistently making yourself do what needs to be done, especially when you don't feel like doing it.
meta.answer_format: Pointed behavioral descriptions replacing generic frequency scale

2.label: Level 2
2.description: Awareness exists but action doesn't follow

5.label: Level 5
5.description: Discipline is integrated - it's who you are

calculation.method: Sum dimension questions, divide by 5, multiply by 2

dimensions.name: Communion
dimensions.description: Discipline in receiving from God through spiritual practices — revelation, presence, grace, calling

scripture_anchor.text: But seek first the kingdom of God and his righteousness, and all these things will be added to you.

questions.text: When my alarm goes off for morning prayer/devotion time, I get up and do it even when I don't feel like it.
questions.principle: Eat the Frog: Do the most important thing first

answers.1: I don't have a set devotion time — spiritual practice happens whenever I think of it (rarely)
answers.2: I've tried setting a morning devotion time but I consistently hit snooze or skip it
answers.3: I get up for devotions some mornings, but tiredness or busyness often wins
answers.4: I usually make it to my devotion time, only missing occasionally when legitimately disrupted
answers.5: My morning devotion time is non-negotiable — I'm up and present even when I don't feel like it

questions.text: I have a specific, scheduled time for prayer and Scripture reading that I protect from other demands.

answers.1: I don't have a scheduled time — I pray and read when the mood strikes or not at all
answers.2: I have a vague idea of when I should do devotions but it's easily overridden by anything else
answers.3: I have a scheduled time but it frequently gets bumped for work, family, or other demands
answers.4: My devotion time is mostly protected — I only adjust for genuine emergencies
answers.5: My spiritual time block is firm — other demands work around it, not the other way around

questions.text: When I miss a day of spiritual disciplines, I return to them the next day without spiraling into guilt or giving up.
questions.principle: Order from chaos, getting back up

answers.1: Missing a day usually turns into weeks — guilt makes me avoid trying again
answers.2: I beat myself up when I miss, which makes returning harder and less likely
answers.3: I sometimes bounce back quickly, other times I spiral into guilt and extended absence
answers.4: I usually return the next day, though I still feel some unnecessary guilt about missing
answers.5: Missing a day is just data — I note it, examine why, and show up the next day without drama

questions.text: I practice Sabbath rest intentionally, even when there's work I could be doing.

answers.1: Rest feels irresponsible to me — I work until I crash, then recover, then repeat
answers.2: I know I should rest but I can't stop the mental churn — work bleeds into every day
answers.3: I try to take Sabbath but often fill it with errands or feel guilty for not being productive
answers.4: I usually protect a rest day, though I occasionally cheat with 'small' work tasks
answers.5: Sabbath is sacred in my calendar — I rest intentionally and without guilt

questions.text: I follow through on spiritual commitments (church attendance, small group, serving) even when inconvenient.
questions.principle: Commitment to the 'why' even when 'what' is hard

answers.1: I show up when it's convenient and skip when anything else comes up
answers.2: I intend to be consistent but frequently bail due to tiredness, weather, or competing plans
answers.3: I attend about half the time — consistency depends on how I'm feeling that week
answers.4: I'm reliable most of the time, only missing for legitimate conflicts or illness
answers.5: My spiritual commitments are in ink — I show up as committed regardless of convenience

remediation.advice: Start with the smallest viable spiritual habit. 5 minutes of prayer before checking your phone. Build consistency before duration. As Brian Tracy teaches: 'Successful people do what unsuccessful people are unwilling to do.'

scripture.text: He who is faithful in a very little thing is faithful also in much.

dimensions.name: Conscience
dimensions.description: Discipline in acting on moral conviction — the faculty that directs spiritual behavior, educated by the Word

scripture_anchor.text: So whoever knows the right thing to do and fails to do it, for him it is sin.

questions.text: When I sense conviction about something (right or wrong), I act on it promptly rather than rationalizing or delaying.
questions.principle: Do not lie, especially to yourself

answers.1: I've gotten skilled at ignoring or explaining away conviction — it rarely changes my behavior
answers.2: I feel conviction but usually talk myself out of acting on it
answers.3: I act on conviction sometimes, but often delay until the urgency fades
answers.4: I usually respond to conviction fairly promptly, though occasionally I drag my feet
answers.5: When conviction hits, I act — delay only makes it harder

questions.text: I confess and make things right quickly when I've wronged someone, even when it's uncomfortable.

answers.1: I avoid confronting wrongs I've done — time heals all wounds, right?
answers.2: I might apologize eventually but I procrastinate until it's awkward to bring up
answers.3: I confess sometimes, but often only when forced or when the discomfort becomes unbearable
answers.4: I usually make things right within a few days, though I dread the conversation
answers.5: I confess quickly — the discomfort of unresolved wrongs is worse than the awkwardness of confession

questions.text: I say 'no' to requests or opportunities that violate my values, even when saying yes would benefit me.

answers.1: I bend my values regularly when there's personal benefit on the line
answers.2: I feel conflicted but usually rationalize why this particular compromise is okay
answers.3: I hold the line on big things but let smaller compromises slide
answers.4: I usually say no to value violations, though some situations really test me
answers.5: My values aren't negotiable — no benefit is worth compromising who I am

questions.text: I keep my word and follow through on commitments, even small ones, even when no one would notice if I didn't.
questions.principle: Your word is your bond with reality

answers.1: I make promises casually and break them just as casually — no one's really keeping track
answers.2: I keep the big commitments but let small ones slide if they become inconvenient
answers.3: I try to keep my word but frequently find reasons why this particular promise doesn't count
answers.4: I'm reliable on most commitments, though occasionally I drop small ones unintentionally
answers.5: My word is my bond — if I said it, I do it, regardless of who's watching

questions.text: When I notice I'm justifying questionable behavior, I stop and examine myself honestly.

answers.1: I'm excellent at justification — I can make almost anything seem reasonable to myself
answers.2: I sometimes notice my rationalizations but usually keep going anyway
answers.3: I catch myself justifying sometimes and occasionally stop to examine it
answers.4: I'm usually able to recognize when I'm making excuses and course correct
answers.5: Self-deception is something I actively guard against — I know my patterns and catch them early

remediation.advice: Jordan Peterson's rule: 'Tell the truth, or at least don't lie.' Start there. Every rationalization weakens your conscience; every honest act strengthens it. Make one difficult confession this week.

scripture.text: If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

dimensions.name: Holiness
dimensions.description: Discipline in maintaining spiritual purity — sanctification, abiding in Christ, lacking leaven

scripture_anchor.text: As obedient children, do not be conformed to the passions of your former ignorance, but as he who called you is holy, you also be holy in all your conduct.

questions.text: When the Holy Spirit convicts me of sin, I confess and repent promptly rather than rationalizing, minimizing, or delaying.
questions.principle: Don't let things fester; face what you're avoiding

answers.1: I've learned to tune out conviction — it's just guilt I don't need
answers.2: I feel conviction but usually minimize the issue or tell myself I'll deal with it later
answers.3: Sometimes I respond quickly, other times I let conviction sit for days or weeks
answers.4: I usually confess and repent fairly promptly, though occasionally I resist
answers.5: Conviction is a gift — when it comes, I stop, confess, and repent without delay

questions.text: I maintain spiritual disciplines even during dry seasons when I don't feel God's presence or see spiritual fruit.
questions.principle: Consistency regardless of feeling; the discipline creates the result

answers.1: When I don't feel anything, I stop showing up — what's the point?
answers.2: Dry seasons knock me off my disciplines quickly — I need to feel something to continue
answers.3: I persist for a while during dry seasons but eventually drift away until things feel better
answers.4: I mostly maintain disciplines in dry seasons, though my commitment wavers
answers.5: Feelings aren't my gauge — I show up whether it feels fruitful or not

questions.text: I actively work to root out areas of habitual sin or compromise rather than tolerating them as 'just how I am.'
questions.principle: Take responsibility; don't rationalize weakness as identity

answers.1: I've accepted my sin patterns as permanent features of my personality
answers.2: I know I should work on these areas but I've given up trying to change
answers.3: I make occasional efforts but quickly return to old patterns
answers.4: I'm actively working on most areas of compromise, with slow but real progress
answers.5: I treat habitual sin as an enemy to be defeated, not a roommate to tolerate

questions.text: I intentionally seek spiritual filling and renewal (worship, solitude, prayer) rather than running on empty until I crash.
questions.principle: Boundaries around spiritual refueling; sustainable holiness

answers.1: I run on spiritual fumes until I'm empty, then wonder why I feel disconnected
answers.2: I know I need spiritual refueling but rarely make time for it until crisis hits
answers.3: I seek renewal sometimes, but often let myself get depleted before I do
answers.4: I usually keep my spiritual tank reasonably full, occasionally letting it get low
answers.5: Spiritual renewal is scheduled and protected — I don't wait until I'm empty

questions.text: I maintain my commitment to holiness in private — when no one would know if I compromised.
questions.principle: Private behavior predicts public character; small disciplines reveal true state

answers.1: My private life and public image are very different — I compromise freely when alone
answers.2: I'm more relaxed in private — small compromises feel harmless when no one sees
answers.3: I try to be consistent but definitely give myself more slack when alone
answers.4: I'm mostly the same in private and public, with occasional private lapses
answers.5: Private holiness is the foundation — my character doesn't change based on who's watching

remediation.advice: Holiness isn't perfection — it's direction. As Jordan Peterson teaches, you must face what you're avoiding. Identify ONE area of compromise you've been tolerating. Confess it. Make a plan to address it.

scripture.text: He who conceals his transgressions will not prosper, but he who confesses and forsakes them will find compassion.

dimensions.name: Mind
dimensions.description: Discipline in learning, growing intellectually, and renewing your thinking

scripture_anchor.text: Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind.

questions.text: I have a consistent practice of reading/learning (books, courses, study) that I maintain even when busy.

answers.1: I rarely read or learn intentionally — information comes passively if at all
answers.2: I buy books and sign up for courses but rarely finish them
answers.3: I learn in bursts when interested, but busyness easily disrupts my habits
answers.4: I maintain a learning practice most of the time, occasionally dropping it when overwhelmed
answers.5: Learning is a non-negotiable habit — I have protected time and I use it

questions.text: I engage in deep thinking (reflection, journaling, analysis) rather than only consuming content passively.

answers.1: I consume content but rarely process it — thinking deeply feels like a luxury I don't have
answers.2: I know I should reflect more but I prefer distraction to the effort of thinking
answers.3: I do some reflection but often skim the surface or get distracted midway
answers.4: I regularly engage in deep thinking, though sometimes I take shortcuts
answers.5: Deep thinking is built into my week — I don't just consume, I process and apply

questions.text: I protect focused thinking time from interruptions and distractions (phone, notifications, multitasking).

answers.1: I'm constantly interrupted and I've stopped trying to control it
answers.2: I try to focus but always keep notifications on 'just in case'
answers.3: I protect focus time sometimes, but often let distractions creep in
answers.4: I usually protect focus time well, with occasional breaches
answers.5: Deep work time is sacred — phone goes away, notifications are off, door is closed

questions.text: When I encounter ideas that challenge my thinking, I engage with them honestly rather than dismissing them.

answers.1: I avoid ideas that challenge me — it's more comfortable to stay in my bubble
answers.2: I encounter challenging ideas but quickly find reasons to dismiss them
answers.3: I engage sometimes, but often only with ideas that don't threaten my core beliefs
answers.4: I usually engage honestly with challenging ideas, though some topics are harder
answers.5: I actively seek ideas that challenge me — being wrong is how I learn

questions.text: I apply what I learn (wisdom) rather than just accumulating knowledge I never use.

answers.1: I collect information without applying it — knowing feels like doing
answers.2: I intend to apply what I learn but rarely follow through
answers.3: I apply some things, but much of what I learn never makes it into practice
answers.4: I usually try to apply one thing from everything I learn
answers.5: Implementation is the point — if I'm not going to apply it, why learn it?

remediation.advice: Brian Tracy: 'Reading one hour per day in your field will make you an expert in 3 years, a national authority in 5 years, and a world-class expert in 7 years.' Start with 15 minutes. But don't just read - apply one thing from everything you learn.

scripture.text: The heart of the discerning acquires knowledge, for the ears of the wise seek it out.

dimensions.name: Will
dimensions.description: Discipline in follow-through — the meta-discipline of executing on your commitments to yourself

scripture_anchor.text: For God gave us a spirit not of fear but of power and love and self-control.

questions.text: When I commit to doing something (to myself or others), I follow through even when it becomes inconvenient.
questions.principle: Integrity with yourself is the foundation

answers.1: I regularly abandon commitments when they get hard or inconvenient
answers.2: I follow through on easy things but back out when real resistance shows up
answers.3: I push through sometimes, but difficulty often wins — it depends on my mood
answers.4: I usually finish what I start, though I occasionally need external accountability
answers.5: Once I commit, I execute — difficulty is expected and doesn't change my course

questions.text: I do hard things I don't want to do because they need to be done, without excessive internal negotiation.
questions.principle: Eat the Frog; do it first

answers.1: I avoid hard things until forced or until the consequences become unbearable
answers.2: I negotiate extensively with myself, often finding reasons why it can wait
answers.3: I do hard things sometimes, but often after significant internal resistance
answers.4: I usually tackle hard things with minimal negotiation, though some tasks really test me
answers.5: Hard things go first — if I don't feel like doing it, that's exactly why I should

questions.text: I make decisions and act on them rather than staying stuck in analysis or procrastination.

answers.1: I get paralyzed by decisions — I research endlessly and often never choose
answers.2: I make decisions slowly and often revisit them, wasting time on second-guessing
answers.3: I decide reasonably well on small things but get stuck on bigger choices
answers.4: I usually make decisions efficiently, occasionally overthinking complex situations
answers.5: I decide, act, and adjust — waiting for perfect information is its own decision (a bad one)

questions.text: When I fail to follow through, I examine why, make adjustments, and try again rather than making excuses.

answers.1: Failure proves I can't do it — I give up and move on to something else
answers.2: I make excuses to protect my ego rather than honestly examining what went wrong
answers.3: Sometimes I examine failures honestly, other times I just feel bad and don't learn
answers.4: I usually analyze failures and try again, though occasionally I repeat the same mistakes
answers.5: Failure is data — I examine it honestly, adjust the approach, and go again

questions.text: I build small disciplines in daily life (bed made, dishes done, space organized) that strengthen my overall will.
questions.principle: Clean your room; small behaviors predict large ones

answers.1: My environment reflects my chaos — small disciplines feel pointless
answers.2: I know small disciplines matter but I can't seem to maintain them
answers.3: I'm disciplined in some small areas but not others — it's inconsistent
answers.4: I maintain most small disciplines, with occasional lapses
answers.5: My environment is ordered because I've made small disciplines automatic

remediation.advice: Jordan Peterson: 'Start by cleaning your room.' This isn't trivial - it's foundational. Every time you override your resistance to do something small, you strengthen the muscle for doing something big. Pick one tiny discipline and make it non-negotiable for 30 days.

scripture.text: But I discipline my body and keep it under control, lest after preaching to others I myself should be disqualified.

dimensions.name: Emotions
dimensions.description: Discipline in processing emotions and managing actions (not feelings themselves)

scripture_anchor.text: Be angry and do not sin; do not let the sun go down on your anger.

questions.text: I feel the full range of emotions throughout the day without those emotions dictating my actions.
questions.principle: Feel the rollercoaster, don't act on the rollercoaster

answers.1: My emotions run the show — when I feel it, I act on it
answers.2: I try to suppress emotions entirely, which leads to explosions
answers.3: I manage some emotions well but others (anger, anxiety) still control me
answers.4: I usually feel without acting impulsively, though strong emotions can still hijack me
answers.5: I feel everything fully — and then I choose my response deliberately

questions.text: I process difficult emotions (journaling, talking, praying) rather than burying or numbing them.

answers.1: I bury or numb difficult emotions — if I don't think about them, they don't exist
answers.2: I know I should process emotions but I prefer distraction to the discomfort
answers.3: I process sometimes but often let things build up until they overflow
answers.4: I usually process difficult emotions, though some get buried longer than they should
answers.5: Processing emotions is scheduled into my life — nothing stays buried

questions.text: I pause before responding when emotionally triggered rather than reacting impulsively.

answers.1: When triggered, I react immediately — the words are out before I think
answers.2: I know I should pause but I rarely manage it in the moment
answers.3: I pause sometimes, but strong triggers still get instant reactions
answers.4: I usually pause before responding, though occasionally I react first
answers.5: Pause is automatic — I've trained myself to create space between trigger and response

questions.text: I have healthy outlets for stress and negative emotions rather than destructive coping mechanisms.

answers.1: My coping mechanisms are mostly destructive — I know it but can't seem to stop
answers.2: I have some healthy outlets but often default to unhealthy ones when stressed
answers.3: I use a mix of healthy and unhealthy coping — depends on how bad it is
answers.4: I mostly use healthy outlets, occasionally slipping into old patterns under pressure
answers.5: I've built a robust set of healthy outlets that I use consistently

questions.text: I address emotional issues in relationships directly rather than letting resentment build or avoiding conflict.

answers.1: I avoid conflict at all costs — resentment builds until the relationship breaks
answers.2: I might address things eventually but usually let issues fester for too long
answers.3: I address some issues directly but avoid the really uncomfortable ones
answers.4: I usually address issues fairly promptly, though sometimes I delay too long
answers.5: I address relational issues quickly and directly — resentment can't build if I don't let it

remediation.advice: The goal isn't to stop feeling - it's to stop letting feelings control actions. Start a simple practice: when triggered, name the emotion out loud ('I'm feeling angry'), take three breaths, then choose your response. As Cloud & Townsend teach: emotions are data, not directives.

scripture.text: Whoever is slow to anger is better than the mighty, and he who rules his spirit than he who takes a city.

dimensions.name: Sustenance
dimensions.description: Discipline in nutrition, sleep, hydration, and environment quality — what sustains the body

scripture_anchor.text: Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit within you?

questions.text: I maintain a consistent sleep schedule (same bedtime and wake time) even on weekends.
questions.principle: Morning routines start with evening discipline

answers.1: My sleep schedule is chaotic — I sleep when I'm exhausted and wake when I have to
answers.2: I have a vague target but rarely hit it — weekends especially are a free-for-all
answers.3: I'm consistent during the week but weekends throw me completely off
answers.4: I mostly maintain my schedule, with occasional deviations
answers.5: My sleep schedule is locked in — same time every day, including weekends

questions.text: I eat in a way that fuels my body well (real food, appropriate portions) rather than giving in to cravings.

answers.1: I eat whatever's convenient — nutrition rarely factors into my choices
answers.2: I know what I should eat but consistently choose otherwise
answers.3: I eat well when it's easy, but stress, busyness, or availability derails me
answers.4: Most of my meals are intentional — I plan and prepare, with occasional lapses
answers.5: Eating well is a settled discipline — I've built systems that make it automatic

questions.text: I drink adequate water throughout the day and limit substances that impair performance (alcohol, excessive caffeine).

answers.1: I run on caffeine and rarely drink water — I notice but don't change
answers.2: I know my substance intake is too high but cutting back feels impossible
answers.3: I manage hydration and substances sometimes, but easily slip into bad patterns
answers.4: I usually stay well hydrated and moderate with substances, with occasional excess
answers.5: Hydration is automatic and I'm intentional about anything that affects my performance

questions.text: I maintain my environment (clean space, organized workspace, reduced toxins/clutter) rather than living in chaos.
questions.principle: Clean your room; environment shapes behavior

answers.1: My environment is chaotic and I've stopped seeing it
answers.2: I clean up occasionally but it quickly returns to disorder
answers.3: Some areas are organized, others are perpetual disaster zones
answers.4: I mostly keep things ordered, with occasional pileups that I address
answers.5: My environment stays clean and organized — I've built systems that maintain it

questions.text: I take breaks and rest when needed rather than pushing through to burnout, then crashing.

answers.1: I push until I crash, recover, repeat — I don't know another way
answers.2: I know I need breaks but taking them feels like weakness
answers.3: I take breaks sometimes but often ignore the signs until it's too late
answers.4: I usually take appropriate breaks, occasionally pushing too hard before I do
answers.5: I've learned my limits and I respect them — breaks are scheduled, not emergency measures

remediation.advice: Start with sleep. Everything else becomes harder when you're tired. Set a non-negotiable bedtime for one week. As Brian Tracy says: 'How you start your morning determines the quality of your entire day.' And how you end your evening determines how you start your morning.

scripture.text: It is in vain that you rise up early and go late to rest, eating the bread of anxious toil; for he gives to his beloved sleep.

dimensions.name: Capability
dimensions.description: Discipline in physical exercise, movement, and building what your body can do

scripture_anchor.text: For while bodily training is of some value, godliness is of value in every way.

questions.text: I exercise regularly according to a schedule rather than only when I feel like it.
questions.principle: Schedule it or it won't happen

answers.1: I don't have an exercise routine — I move when I have to and otherwise don't
answers.2: I've tried many exercise schedules but can't stick with any of them
answers.3: I exercise in bursts — consistent for a while, then completely off
answers.4: I have a regular schedule I mostly keep, with occasional missed sessions
answers.5: Exercise is blocked in my calendar and I show up — feeling like it isn't required

questions.text: I do my planned workout even when I don't feel motivated, knowing motivation follows action.
questions.principle: Action creates motivation; do it anyway

answers.1: No motivation means no workout — I need to feel like it before I'll do it
answers.2: I often skip workouts when not motivated, planning to make up for it later (I don't)
answers.3: Sometimes I push through lack of motivation, other times it wins
answers.4: I usually do the workout even unmotivated, though occasionally I negotiate down
answers.5: Motivation is irrelevant — the workout happens whether I feel like it or not

questions.text: I incorporate movement throughout my day (standing, walking, stretching) rather than being sedentary for long periods.

answers.1: I sit for hours without moving and only realize it when something hurts
answers.2: I know I should move more but I don't actually do it
answers.3: I incorporate some movement but often forget for long stretches
answers.4: I usually build movement into my day, occasionally getting trapped at my desk
answers.5: Movement is built into my day — I have triggers and habits that keep me from being sedentary

questions.text: I progressively challenge my body (increased weight, distance, intensity) rather than staying in my comfort zone.
questions.principle: Voluntary exposure to challenge makes you stronger

answers.1: I don't challenge myself physically — I stay well within what's comfortable
answers.2: I've been doing the same routine at the same level for years
answers.3: I occasionally push myself but often coast at a comfortable level
answers.4: I usually progress my training, though sometimes I plateau by not pushing
answers.5: Progressive challenge is the point — I track, measure, and deliberately increase

questions.text: I maintain my exercise habit even during travel, busy seasons, or disrupted routines.

answers.1: Any disruption ends my exercise routine — I'll restart when things settle (they don't)
answers.2: I try to maintain during disruptions but usually fail within days
answers.3: I keep up some exercise during disruptions but at much reduced frequency
answers.4: I mostly maintain during disruptions, adapting my routine as needed
answers.5: Routine disruptions don't stop me — I have travel workouts, backup plans, and minimal options

remediation.advice: Don't start with an ambitious program you'll quit. Start with something so small it's embarrassing: 5 pushups. 10-minute walk. The goal is building the discipline, not the fitness - fitness comes later. Brian Tracy: 'The first hour is the rudder of the day.' If morning exercise doesn't work, find a time that does and protect it.

scripture.text: Do you not know that in a race all the runners run, but only one receives the prize? So run that you may obtain it.

dimensions.name: Wholeness
dimensions.description: Discipline in preventive care, addressing issues, and maintaining integrated wellness

scripture_anchor.text: Beloved, I pray that all may go well with you and that you may be in good health, as it goes well with your soul.

questions.text: I schedule and attend regular preventive care (checkups, dental, vision) rather than only going when something is wrong.

answers.1: I only see doctors when something is really wrong — preventive care feels unnecessary
answers.2: I know I should get checkups but I keep postponing them
answers.3: I'm current on some preventive care but way behind on others
answers.4: I mostly stay on top of preventive care, occasionally falling behind
answers.5: Preventive care is scheduled and I show up — maintenance is easier than repair

questions.text: When I notice a health issue (pain, symptom, concern), I address it promptly rather than ignoring it.
questions.principle: Don't ignore the small problems; they grow

answers.1: I ignore health issues until they become impossible to ignore
answers.2: I notice things but convince myself it's probably nothing and hope it goes away
answers.3: I address some issues promptly but let others linger for too long
answers.4: I usually address health issues fairly quickly, occasionally delaying
answers.5: I don't let things fester — if something's off, I address it before it grows

questions.text: I follow through on medical recommendations (medication, therapy, lifestyle changes) even when inconvenient.

answers.1: I get recommendations and then ignore them
answers.2: I start following recommendations but quickly fall off
answers.3: I follow some recommendations but not others — depends on how inconvenient they are
answers.4: I mostly follow through on recommendations, occasionally skipping or forgetting
answers.5: If I've agreed to a treatment plan, I execute it fully — that's the point

questions.text: I manage chronic conditions or health maintenance routines consistently rather than sporadically.
questions.principle: Systems beat willpower; routine creates results

answers.1: I'm inconsistent with health routines and it shows
answers.2: I manage routines for a while then completely drop them
answers.3: I'm consistent with some routines but others are hit or miss
answers.4: I mostly maintain my health routines, with occasional lapses
answers.5: Health maintenance is built into my life — it happens automatically

questions.text: I recognize that physical, mental, and spiritual health are connected and address my body as an integrated whole.

answers.1: I treat symptoms in isolation without seeing how they connect
answers.2: I intellectually know they're connected but I don't act on it
answers.3: I sometimes address health holistically, other times I just treat what hurts
answers.4: I usually take an integrated approach, though occasionally I get tunnel vision
answers.5: Holistic health is my operating assumption — I look for root causes and connections

remediation.advice: What have you been avoiding? That nagging pain, the checkup you've postponed, the issue you pretend isn't there? Jordan Peterson: 'What you most need to find is where you least want to look.' Schedule one appointment this week that you've been putting off.

scripture.text: Is anyone among you sick? Let him call for the elders of the church, and let them pray over him.

overall_interpretation.crisis: Any dimension scoring 1-4 needs immediate attention. Apply remediation principle: if Discipline is weak, shore up Responsibility (Layer 3). Go down layers until you find solid ground.
overall_interpretation.maintenance: Dimensions scoring 5-6 are functional but not growing. Maintain these while focusing progress elsewhere.
overall_interpretation.strength: Dimensions scoring 7+ are your dauntless zones. You're prepared when trials come in these areas.
overall_interpretation.integration: No dimension exists in isolation. Spirit, Soul, and Body affect each other. Neglect in one area will eventually impact others.

next_steps: Identify 1-2 crisis areas (if any) for immediate intervention
Choose 2-3 focus areas for this season's growth
For each focus area, implement ONE small discipline improvement
